conclusion: Analyzing the particle's motion step by step to determine when the speed equals 5 m/s.
The graph shows displacement x (in meters) versus time t (in seconds).
The particle starts at x = 10 m at t = 0 s, passes through x = 0 m at around t = 2 s, and ends at x = -10 m at t = 4 s.
The particle starts at a positive displacement (10 m) and ends at a negative displacement (-10 m).
The curve is smooth, suggesting continuous motion.
The displacement decreases throughout, meaning the particle moves in the negative direction the entire time.
Velocity is the rate of change of displacement with time (the derivative of the position function or the slope of the displacement-time graph).
From 0 to 2 seconds: The slope is negative but gradually becoming steeper (more negative), indicating the speed is increasing.
At around t = 2 seconds: The curve is steepest, suggesting maximum speed.
From 2 to 4 seconds: The slope is still negative but becoming less steep, indicating the speed is decreasing.
The speed is 5 m/s when the velocity is either +5 m/s or -5 m/s.
Since the particle is moving in the negative direction throughout, we're looking for when velocity = -5 m/s.
To find when velocity = -5 m/s, identify where the slope of the displacement curve equals -5.
Initially (t = 0), the slope appears to be small in magnitude (close to 0).
The slope becomes steeper (more negative) until around t = 2s.
After t = 2s, the slope becomes less steep again.
Velocity equals -5 m/s at two points: once during the 0-2s interval as the particle accelerates, and once during the 2-4s interval as the particle decelerates.
There are 2 moments when the speed is 5 m/s: once before t = 2s when the particle is accelerating, and once after t = 2s when the particle is decelerating.
